content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits
    value::Float64
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, u::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(u.value) $(u.unit)")
end
```
In this code, the `FloatWithUnits` struct is defined with two fields: `value` of type `Float64` and `unit` of type `String`. The `Base.show` method is overridden to print the `FloatWithUnits` object as a string in the desired format. This is done by defining the function to print the `value` and `unit` fields of the object, separated by a space.
